docs.lead_paragraph: For most of the decade, supporters of abortion rights at the Connecticut Capitol wanted little more than to bask in the state's reputation for friendliness toward their agenda. They had insurance -- in 1990, the Legislature had enacted the provisions of Roe v. Wade into state law, in case the Supreme Court ever reversed that decision -- and a vote on any other abortion measure was seen by women's groups as asking for trouble. So for the last nine years, as political careers elsewhere were staked on such fights as whether parents should consent to a teen-ager's planned abortion or merely be notified about it, legislative leaders in Hartford did not even permit a debate on an abortion bill.

headline.main: Political Memo; In Hartford, New Battleground for an Abortion Debate

docs.abstract: Connecticut Legislature, firm bastion of abortion rights, holds first vote on subject in years, under two-bill deal brokered by new Speaker, Moira K Lyons; bill requiring insurance coverage of prescription birth control is approved overwhelmingly, while bill to ban late-term abortion procedure is defeated, leaving anti-abortion groups further behind than ever (M)
docs.snippet: For most of the decade, supporters of abortion rights at the Connecticut Capitol wanted little more than to bask in the state's reputation for friendliness toward their agenda. They had insurance -- in 1990, the Legislature had enacted the provisions...

docs.lead_paragraph: IT is a warm spring evening and a half dozen children are out on the sidewalk, running up and down the hilly tree-lined street, playing. This is an older part of Staten Island, and some of the pleasingly proportioned two-story houses have been here since the early years of this century. In the backyard of the house with the big pointy evergreen that nearly obscures its face, Daniel Graham is sweeping the concrete patio, talking about his plans. He'll renovate the large eat-in kitchen, where the wiring is so quirky that if he wants to turn on the light near the table he has to first turn on the porch light.

headline.main: Habitats/West Brighton, Staten Island; A Place to Run Freely

docs.abstract: Interview with Daniel Graham about renovations he is making to his Staten Island home (Habitats column); photo (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: THE Senate made a bit of history last week, passing gun-control legislation that had been left for dead just a week before. The measures are modest, which may suggest that anti-gun-control forces remain powerful despite concern over shooting incidents at schools. But the fact that they passed at all suggests that a center may be forming in a debate that has been dominated by two extremes.

headline.main: The Nation; The Gun Debate Has Two Sides. Now, a Third Way.

docs.abstract: Senate's passage of modest gun-control legislation reviewed; photo (M)
docs.snippet: THE Senate made a bit of history last week, passing gun-control legislation that had been left for dead just a week before.    The measures are modest, which may suggest that anti-gun-control forces remain powerful despite concern over shooting...

docs.lead_paragraph: Maybe they should have just stenciled it in large letters on Andrew Goldstein's forehead: ''ticking time bomb. suffers schizophrenia. if off medication, run for cover!'' The news accounts of his arrest for pushing Kendra Webdale under a subway train in New York that first Sunday afternoon in January must have sent a cold shiver through the hundreds of psychiatrists, therapists and social workers who had treated this seriously mentally ill man. They knew he was dangerous. In the two years before Kendra Webdale was instantly killed on the tracks, Andrew Goldstein attacked at least 13 other people. The hospital staff members who kept treating and discharging Goldstein knew that he repeatedly attacked strangers in public places. They knew because he had attacked them -- two psychiatrists, a nurse, a social worker and a therapy aide in two years' time. Over and over, his hospital charts carried warnings.
docs.abstract: Michael Winerip article discusses case of Andrew Goldstein mentally ill man with history of assault that culminated in January with murder of Kendra Webdale, who Goldstein pushed under subway train in New York City; notes Goldstein voluntarily sought professional help at various state hospitals, cooperated with psychiatrists and made number of attempts to obtain long-term hospitalization at Creedmoor, state hospital; maintains there is long list of institutions and individuals who should be held accountable for what happened to Goldstein and Webdale, but at the top of the list belong Gov Pataki and the State of New York, for it is states that have primarily responsibility for citizens who are mentally ill, and it is the states that have persistently shirked that responsibility; photos (L)
docs.snippet: Maybe they should have just stenciled it in large letters on Andrew Goldstein's forehead: ''ticking time bomb. suffers schizophrenia. if off medication, run for cover!'' The news accounts of his arrest for pushing Kendra Webdale under a subway train...

docs.lead_paragraph: IT took 30 pounds of hot dogs, 1,000 chicken sandwiches, 3,941 bottles of water, 2,520 bottles of juice, 9,400 paper cups and 3,500 people to raise $315,000 -- after expenses -- on a recent walkathon sponsored by the Northern Metro Chapter of the March of Dimes here. It also involved thousands of metal button pins that read ''I Did It!'' -- along with T-shirts, hats and balloons -- for the walkers. Add to that the effort of printing hundreds of signs that marked checkpoints, first aid stations, locations of portable toilets and food tables along three 8- to 10-mile routes laid out for the walkers, along with the printing of brochures, envelopes and other materials.

headline.main: Cast of Thousands Raises Money for Dozens of Worthy Causes

docs.abstract: Thousands of walkers raise $315,000 at recent walkathon sponsored by Northern Metro Chapter of March of Dimes in White Plains, NY; photos (Special Section: Summer Calculations) (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: Health insurance companies are proposing new Federal programs and tax breaks to subsidize insurance for millions of people without coverage. The insurance industry, which helped kill President Clinton's plan to guarantee coverage for all Americans in 1994, said it had become alarmed at the growing number of uninsured.

headline.main: Insurers Ask Government To Extend Health Plans

docs.abstract: Health Insurance Association of America proposes new Federal programs and tax breaks to subsidize insurance for 28 million Americans without coverage; proposals would amount to huge new Federal subsidy of industry, but Leonard D Schaeffer, association's chairman, says most of money would be passed on to doctors, hospitals and others who provide health care; cost could be as much as $60 billion a year, but association says Congress could start with parts of the plan costing much less (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: To the Editor: ''Temporarily Yours'' (Preludes, April 18) noted the boom in temporary work but not the sobering fact that a large number of temps are trapped in these precarious work arrangements, and in most cases without job security and employee benefits.

headline.main: For Temporary Workers, A Full-Time Quandary

docs.abstract: Rep Lane Evans letter, commenting on April 18 article on temporary employment, says he will be introducing legislation to prohibit employers from using it to evade their legal and moral responsibilities to their employees

docs.lead_paragraph: State officials, fresh from the chore of cleaning up the bankruptcy and liquidation of HIP Health Plans of New Jersey, said this week that the rapidly evolving health insurance industry could still present new problems. Testifying today before the Senate Health Committee, Jaynee LaVecchia, the Commissioner of the Department of Banking and Insurance, said that she was beginning to see deals that were disturbingly similar to the one that brought on the demise of HIP, which had been the state's fourth-largest health maintenance organization.

headline.main: State Says Potential Pitfalls Still Plague H.M.O. Industry

docs.abstract: Banking and Insurance Comr Jaynee LaVecchia and other officials, testifying before State Senate Health Committee on bankruptcy and liquidation of HIP Health Plans of New Jersey, say rapidly evolving health insurance industry can still present new problems; LaVecchia says she is beginning to see deals that were similar to one that brought on demise of HIP, which had been state's fourth-largest health maintenance organization (M)
